page.title: 02Geology
page.content: The eastward facing sea cliffs that run from the northern point of Le Colombier to just short of the jetty at Bouley Bay itself are formed of two main rock types:{rhyolitic and } {andesitic volcanic rocks.}Some striking{spherulitic}rhyolites are to be found north of the Bouley Bay jetty. The cliffs above Vicard are different; here a{Cambro-Ordovician } {conglomerate}forms a small outlier. A second outlier of this conglomerate forms the southward running valley in the SW corner of the block. The Tour de Rozel, across Bouley Bay on its eastern side, if also formed of the conglomerate but here it is part of the main outcrop. The small valley in the conglomerate is a partly{exhumed valley}of Cambro-Ordovician times.
